- Events: event1 and event2.

Step 2 — transition rules
- “After event2, event1 must happen.” Meaning: whenever event2 occurs, there must be a (possibly later) occurrence of event1 after it.
- “After event1, event2 must happen.” Meaning: whenever event1 occurs, there must be a (possibly later) occurrence of event2 after it.
- Together these force that occurrences of the two events alternate in the future: from the initial event1 you get event2 sometime later, then event1 sometime later, then event2, etc. (The rules require eventual occurrences but do not force them to happen immediately — delays with no events between occurrences are allowed unless the model forbids idle steps.)

Step 3 — meaning of C1, C2, C3, C4
- C1: “Event2 happens or event1 happens.” This is ambiguous: it can be read as a state property (“right now, either event2 occurs or event1 occurs”) or as a temporal property (“at some time (now or later), event2 or event1 happens” / “eventually event1 or event2 happens”).
- C2: same as C1.
- C3: “C1 holds or C2 holds.” Since C1 and C2 are the same, C3 is equivalent to C1.
- C4: “C3 always holds.” That means “at every time point, C3 is true” (again depending on whether C1 was intended as a “now” or “eventually” statement).

Step 4 — how they relate and whether C4 is true
- Under the usual reading that C1 means “right now either event1 or event2 occurs”: C4 is False. Counterexample timeline:
  - t=0: event1 occurs (initial).
  - t=1: no event.
  - t=2: event2 occurs.

- Under the reading that C1 means “eventually (from now) event1 or event2 will happen” (i.e., a liveness/“eventually” statement), then C1 is true at every time point (the alternation rules guarantee future occurrences), so C4 would be True.

Conclusion
- If “happens” in C1/C3/C4 means “happens right now”: C4 is False.
- If “happens” means “will happen eventually” (an eventuality/liveness claim): C4 is True.

If you meant one interpretation in particular, tell me which and I’ll restate the result just for that reading.

1) What events are involved and what are the initial conditions?
- Events: event1 and event2.

- Rule A: “After event2, no other events can happen.” So once event2 has occurred, the run has no further events.
- Rule B: “After event1, event2 must happen.” If event1 ever occurs at some time, then at some (later or possibly the same) time event2 must occur afterwards.

3) What does each sub-condition mean?
- C1: “Event1 happens or event2 happens.” (a disjunction)
- C2: same as C1.
- C3: C1 and C2 — i.e. the same disjunction holds (twice), so C3 is equivalent to C1 (and C2).
- C4: “C3 always holds.” This is a temporal claim meaning: at every time point in the run, C3 is true (often written G C3).

Note: There are two reasonable readings of “EventX happens” in C1/C2:
  A. Instantaneous/current-time reading: “EventX happens” is true only at the time instant when that event occurs (a proposition true at the moment of the event).
  B. Existential-over-run reading: “EventX happens” means “EventX occurs at some time in the entire run” (a global fact about the trace).

4) How do these conditions relate to each other (and what's C4)?
- Under reading B (existential over the whole run):
  - The run contains event2 (initially), so “event2 happens” is true as a global fact. Thus C1 and C2 are true; C3 (their conjunction) is true; since these are global truths about the run, “always C3” is also true. So C4 would be True.

- Under reading A (instantaneous/current-time reading), which is the usual interpretation when “always” (G) is used and C1 is a propositional condition evaluated at each time point:
  - At time 0, event2 happens, so C1 and C2 hold at time 0 and C3 holds at time 0.

  - Therefore C3 is not true at every time point, so “always C3” (C4) is false.

Conclusion (most natural temporal-logic reading)
- If we treat “happens” as a time-local predicate and C4 as a temporal-operator claim (“C3 holds at every time”), then C4 is False.
- If instead “happens” means “occurs somewhere in the run” (a global existential), then C4 is True.  

Given the presence of the temporal word “always,” the intended/standard reading is the time-local one, so the correct answer is: C4 is False.

1) Events and initial conditions
- Events: event1 and event2.

2) Transition rules
- After event2, no other events can happen (so once event2 occurs the system has no further event transitions).
- After event1, event2 must happen (if event1 ever occurs, it is followed by event2).

3) Meaning of the sub-conditions
- C1: "Event1 happens in the next state." (a proposition about the immediate next state)
- C2: "C1 eventually holds." (at some future point C1 is true)
- C3: "If C2 holds, then event1 happens." (C2 → event1)
- C4: "C3 holds or event1 happens." (C3 ∨ event1)

4) How they relate / truth values
- Because event2 has occurred initially and after event2 no other events can happen, event1 never happens at any future time. Thus:
  - C1 is false (event1 does not occur in the next state).
  - C2 is false (C1 never becomes true at any future point).
  - C3 is true: an implication with a false antecedent (C2) is true (vacuously true).
  - C4 = (C3 ∨ event1) is therefore true because C3 is true (the disjunction holds regardless of event1).

Therefore C4 is True.

=== Step 2: Solution ===
True
